definitions: independently minded and refusing to conform to accepted norms or conventions
referring to unbranded cattle or animals without an owner's mark
examples: His maverick approach to business shocked traditional investors
The maverick scientist challenged the established theories
The cowboys rounded up several maverick calves on the range
Maverick cattle often mingled with the branded herds

definitions: reaching to the ankle or floor, especially referring to dresses or skirts
examples: She wore a flowing maxi dress to the beach party
The maxi skirt swayed gracefully as she walked

definitions: being the greatest or largest amount, degree, or value possible under given conditions
examples: The system achieved maximal efficiency under optimal conditions
She trained with maximal effort for the competition

definitions: making something as large or great as possible within given constraints
examples: The company adopted a profit maximising strategy last year
Their maximising efforts resulted in record-breaking sales

definitions: making something as large or great as possible within given constraints
examples: The maximizing algorithm improved the system's performance significantly
They focused on maximizing customer satisfaction this quarter

definitions: being the greatest amount, size, or intensity that is possible or recorded
denoting the upper limit permitted by law, regulation, or physical constraints
examples: The car reached its maximum speed on the highway
Maximum capacity for the venue is three thousand people
The maximum penalty for this offense is five years
Students can take a maximum load of eighteen credits

definitions: relating to or characteristic of a mayor or the office of mayor
examples: The mayoral election attracted unprecedented voter turnout this year
Her mayoral duties included attending numerous civic events

definitions: lacking in quantity or quality; scanty, inadequate, or insufficient in amount
examples: They survived on meager rations during the long winter
His meager salary barely covered the monthly expenses

definitions: lacking in quantity or quality; scanty, inadequate, or insufficient in amount
examples: The refugees received only meagre supplies from the agency
Her meagre savings wouldn't last through the recession

definitions: having a dry, crumbly texture resembling coarse flour or meal
having an unhealthy pale appearance or lacking in color and vitality
examples: The overcooked potatoes had a mealy texture nobody enjoyed
These mealy apples are perfect for making sauce
His mealy complexion suggested he hadn't seen sunlight in months
The patient's mealy skin tone concerned the doctor

definitions: unkind, cruel, or unfair in behavior toward others deliberately
constituting the average or middle point between extremes in mathematics
poor in quality, inferior, or below normal standards of excellence
unwilling to share or spend money; stingy and ungenerous with resources
examples: His mean comments about her appearance were completely unnecessary
Don't be mean to your little sister
The mean temperature for July was seventy-five degrees
Calculate the mean value of these data points
They lived in mean circumstances on the poor side of town
The mean accommodations barely provided basic shelter
He was too mean to buy proper Christmas presents
Her mean habits made her unpopular with friends

definitions: following a winding, twisting course without a direct path or destination
proceeding aimlessly without clear purpose or direction in speech or thought
examples: The meandering river carved its way through the valley
We followed the meandering path through the ancient forest
His meandering speech lost the audience's attention quickly
The meandering conversation never reached any conclusion

definitions: intended to communicate or express something significant beyond the surface
examples: She gave him a meaning look across the crowded room
His meaning glance warned her to stay quiet

definitions: having serious, important, or useful quality and purpose that matters
communicating something unspoken but significant through expression or gesture
examples: They had a meaningful discussion about their future together
She wanted to do meaningful work that helped others
He gave her a meaningful smile when she entered
Their meaningful silence spoke volumes about their feelings

definitions: having no meaning, purpose, significance, or value; empty and pointless
examples: The accident rendered all their careful planning meaningless
Life felt meaningless after she lost her job

definitions: capable of being measured or quantified using standard units or methods
large or significant enough to be noticed, detected, or worth considering
examples: The new policy produced measurable improvements in efficiency
Temperature changes are easily measurable with modern instruments
There was no measurable difference between the two groups
The drug showed measurable benefits for most patients

definitions: carefully considered and controlled in manner, speech, or action; deliberate
having a slow, steady, and deliberate rhythm or pace in movement
examples: She responded in measured tones despite her anger
His measured approach to reform won widespread support
The soldiers marched with measured steps across the square
He spoke in measured cadences that held attention

definitions: containing a lot of meat or having the taste and texture of meat
containing substantial, interesting, or thought-provoking content worth serious consideration
examples: The meaty stew satisfied even the hungriest workers
These meaty mushrooms make an excellent vegetarian substitute
The report contained several meaty topics for discussion
She always chooses meaty roles that challenge her abilities

definitions: of or relating to manual work or mechanical devices rather than theory
examples: He learned mechanic arts at the technical school
The mechanic skills required years of practice

definitions: operated by or relating to machinery or physical forces rather than human control
done automatically without thought, feeling, or spontaneity; routine and lifeless
relating to the branch of physics dealing with motion and forces
examples: The mechanical failure caused the production line to stop
They replaced the manual system with mechanical controls
Her mechanical response showed she wasn't really listening
His mechanical smile never reached his eyes
Students studied mechanical engineering at the university
The mechanical properties of materials determine their uses

definitions: equipped with machines or automatic devices to replace human or animal labor
examples: The mechanised farming equipment transformed agricultural productivity
Their mechanised infantry division moved quickly across terrain

definitions: relating to theories that explain phenomena in purely physical or mechanical terms only
examples: His mechanistic view of human behavior ignored emotional factors
The mechanistic model couldn't explain the complex biological processes

definitions: equipped with machines or automatic devices to replace human or animal labor
examples: The mechanized assembly line increased production by threefold
Modern mechanized warfare requires sophisticated logistics support

definitions: interfering in matters that are not one's concern, especially in an annoying way
examples: Her meddling neighbors constantly asked about her personal life
The meddling bureaucrats made the simple process complicated

definitions: relating to or characteristic of the Middle Ages period in European history
examples: The mediaeval castle dominated the hilltop for centuries
They studied mediaeval manuscripts in the ancient library

definitions: situated in the middle or toward the median plane or midline of something
examples: The medial nerve runs through the center of the arm
Surgeons repaired the medial ligament in her knee

definitions: denoting the middle value in a ordered set of statistical data
situated in or passing through the middle position of something
examples: The median income for the area was fifty thousand dollars
Calculate the median score from all test results
The median strip divided the highway into two directions
They planted trees along the median line

definitions: connected or acting through an intervening medium or agency rather than directly
examples: The mediate cause of the conflict was economic inequality
Their mediate relationship made communication difficult

definitions: brought about or transmitted through an intervening agency, mechanism, or medium
examples: The mediated learning experience helped students grasp concepts better
Their mediated communication through lawyers prolonged the divorce

definitions: relating to the science or practice of medicine and the treatment of illness
examples: She received excellent medical care at the hospital
The medical examination revealed no serious problems

definitions: having healing properties or used in medicine to treat or prevent disease
examples: Many plants have medicinal properties that scientists still study
The medicinal herbs grew wild in the mountain valleys

definitions: relating to or characteristic of the Middle Ages period in European history
examples: The medieval fortress stood unchanged for eight hundred years
Students examined medieval art in the museum collection

definitions: of only moderate or average quality; neither good nor bad but disappointing
examples: The restaurant served mediocre food at premium prices
His mediocre performance failed to impress the judges

definitions: involving or absorbed in meditation or deep thought; contemplative and reflective
examples: She sat in meditative silence beside the lake
His meditative mood lasted throughout the evening

definitions: of middle size, degree, or amount between extremes; moderate
halfway between extremes of a quality, neither rare nor well-done
examples: She ordered a medium coffee with extra cream
The medium boxes fit perfectly in the storage unit
He preferred his steak cooked medium rather than rare
The test was of medium difficulty for most students

definitions: quiet, gentle, and easily imposed on; submissive and lacking in spirit
examples: The meek child never complained about the unfair treatment
His meek acceptance of criticism surprised his colleagues

definitions: suitable, fit, or proper for a particular purpose or circumstance
examples: It seemed meet that they should gather to honor him
The committee deemed it meet to postpone the decision

definitions: relating to or denoting prehistoric monuments made of or containing large stones
examples: The megalithic structures at Stonehenge attract millions of visitors
Archaeologists discovered megalithic tombs dating back five thousand years

definitions: feeling or expressing a pensive sadness, typically with no obvious cause
examples: The melancholic music matched her somber mood perfectly
He had a melancholic temperament that colored his worldview

definitions: having a feeling of pensive sadness, typically with no obvious cause
examples: The melancholy tone of the poem moved readers deeply
She felt melancholy watching the last leaves fall

definitions: soft, mature, and rich in flavor, color, or sound from aging
relaxed, gentle, and good-humored through maturity or experience
examples: The mellow wine had aged in oak barrels for years
Autumn brought mellow golden light to the countryside
He became more mellow and tolerant with age
The mellow atmosphere made everyone feel comfortable

definitions: relating to or having melody; tuneful and pleasant sounding musically
examples: The melodic lines in the composition were hauntingly beautiful
Her melodic voice captivated the entire audience

definitions: having a pleasant tune or sound; sweet and musical to hear
examples: The melodious birdsong filled the morning air
Her melodious laughter brightened everyone's day

definitions: exaggerated, sensationalized, or overemotional in behavior or expression; theatrical
examples: Her melodramatic reaction to the minor setback annoyed everyone
The actor's melodramatic performance ruined the serious scene

definitions: having been changed from a solid to a liquid state by heat
examples: The melted chocolate dripped down the sides of the cake
They poured melted butter over the fresh vegetables

definitions: in the process of changing from solid to liquid state through heat
so gentle, tender or emotional as to soften one's feelings
examples: The melting ice created puddles on the sidewalk
Add the melting chocolate slowly to the mixture
Her melting smile made him forget his anger instantly
The puppy's melting eyes convinced them to adopt it

definitions: having limbs or members of a specified number or kind
examples: The six membered ring structure is common in organic chemistry
These multi membered organizations span several countries

definitions: consisting of, resembling, or having the nature of a thin flexible tissue
examples: The membranous wings of the insect were nearly transparent
Doctors examined the membranous lining of the organ

definitions: worth remembering or easily remembered, especially because of being special or unusual
examples: Their wedding was a truly memorable occasion for everyone
She gave a memorable performance that critics still discuss

definitions: suggesting the presence of danger or harm; threatening and intimidating
examples: The menacing clouds promised a violent storm ahead
His menacing demeanor frightened the smaller children
